head.title: A Design for Safer Child Seats

hedline.hl1: A Design for Safer Child Seats

block.p: A NEW means of attaching child-safety seats in cars could result in seats that are safer and easier to install.

A NEW means of attaching child-safety seats in cars could result in seats that are safer and easier to install.

Child seats now buckle into a car's regular seat belts, and safety experts say they are often misinstalled, putting children at risk. Last year, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration convened a panel of experts to examine ways to make child seats and vehicles more compatible.

The panel soon determined that a car's safety belts should not be used to anchor the child seats -- because installation varied widely from car to car and seat to seat -- and it advocated the adoption of a European system called Isofix. The Isofix child seats have built-in steel bars that snap into special brackets in a car. Child seat makers and some auto manufacturers, including Ford, had pledged to move forward with the Isofix system by the 1998 model year.

But since then, General Motors; Evenflo, a child-safety-seat maker, and some suppliers of seat belt components have developed a prototype seat and anchor system. Their new seat has belts with buckles on each side that attach to two soft anchors in the space where a car's back and bottom seat cushions come together. To install the seat, an adult simply buckles the belts into the special anchors and pulls the straps tight.

In clinics of 400 consumers recently conducted by G.M., the double-strap seat was deemed the most desirable of five prototypes. The Isofix seat was judged least desirable because of its weight, complexity and cost -- estimated at $175, compared with about $100 for the dual-strap seat.

The moderator of the safety administration panel, Phil Haseltine, president of the American Coalition of Traffic Safety, said that before the dual-strap seat could go into production, it would require further engineering and testing. He said he was optimistic that the system could be in 1998-model cars, if the agency gave its approval. An agency official, Barry Felrice, said, "We're elated they have come up with an alternative that appears to be more user-friendly."
